subdebateinfo.title: Armed Forces: Training in Malaysia (Question No. 902)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice:

quote.para: On what occasions and to what extent have units of the Australian forces trained or operated besides units of the Malaysian or Singapore forces?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Elements of the three Australian Services cooperated with Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency of 1948 to 1960 in operations against Communist terrorists. These activities included some limited naval bombardment support, ground operations and bomber, fighter and ground support operations. The Australian Army subsequently continued operations in the Thai-Malay border area in conjunction with operations by Malaysian forces.

During the period of Indonesia's confrontation of Malaysia the RAN undertook extensive patrolling activities with the Royal Malaysian Navy, units of the Australian Army were engaged in ground operations in Borneo and the Malayan Peninsula in conjunction with the Malaysian Army and Police Field Force and the RAAF provided fighter and air transport support for the Malaysian forces in those areas.

Our forces have trained with the Malaysian forces as necessary, Service personnel of Malaysia and Singapore have attended training courses at Australian Service establishments under the Government's defence aid to Malaysia and Singapore programme and at the request of the Malaysian Government we have for some years provided officers on secondment to the three Malaysian Services.

subdebate.1.para: Medical Personnel: Recognition of Qualifications (Question No. 913)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: Provisions exist in the legislation of each State and the internal Territories for the recognition of qualifications obtained from recognised training institutions in the other States for the purpose of registration as medical practitioners, pharmacists and nurses. Registration in one State or Territory, however, is not of itself necessarily recognised as a qualification for registration in another State or Territory. Each State and Territory has separate registration requirements concerning overseas qualifications. Registration in a State or Territory on the basis of such qualifications will not enable that person to be registered in another State or Territory if that person's basic overseas qualifications are not recognised in that State or Territory. The details of the registration requirements of each State and Territory are extensive and are contained in the various Acts and Ordinances as follows:

Tasmania- Medical Act 1959-1966.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Pharmacists -

subdebate.1.para: New South Wales - Pharmacy Act 1964.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Nurses -

subdebate.1.para: New South Wales - Nurses Registration Act 1953-1967.
Victoria - Nurses Act 1958 as amended.
Queensland - The Nurses Act of 1964.

Western Australia - Nurses Registration Act 1921-1959.
Tasmania - Nurses Registration Act 1952- 1968.
Australian Capital Territory - Nurses Registration Ordinance 1933-1967.
Northern Territory - Nurses Registration Ordinance 1928-1967.

item.para: Generally, substantial uniformity has been reached by the States and Territories registration authorities as far as qualifications obtained in Australia are concerned. There are, however, areas of difference regarding the acceptance of overseas qualifications, including the recognition by one State of the overseas qualifications of a person registered in another State on the basis of these qualifications.

subdebate.1.para: As regards the recognition of overseas medical qualifications, for a number of years now State and Territory medical practitioners registration authorities have been meeting at irregular intervals.

At the recent meeting held in June of this year, the question of a uniform attitude to overseas qualifications was again discussed. It was decided that problems associated with a uniform approach should be further considered by the several State and Territory Boards. The question has also been considered by conferences of Commonwealth and State Health Ministers. At the June 1968 meeting it was noted that the conference of presidents of the various Boards had the matter listed for consideration.

My colleague, the Minister for Immigration, is encouraging uniformity of registration requirements so far as overseas qualifications are concerned in respect of all professional groups and has discussed the problem in conference with appropriate State Ministers. In so far as the recognition of overseas professional qualifications is concerned the efforts of the Minister for Immigration have my full support. I have submitted the views of the Minister for Immigration to the State Ministers for Health. Efforts towards uniformity will be continued.

asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Did the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works suggest in May that the Commonwealth initiate discussions with the States with a view to establishing an agency responsible for the collection, evaluation and dissemination of hospital planning and design information?

Did the Commonwealth and State Health Ministers at their conference in Darwin in June agree that a meeting of appropriate Commonwealth and State officers should be convened to discuss the proposal in greater detail (Hansard, 17th September 1968, page 1149)?
Have Commonwealth and State officers yet met to discuss the proposal? If so, on what dates and with what results?
Why did the Director-General not refer to this proposal in his report of the Department's activities for the year ended 30th June 1968?
Why did the Ministers not make a public statement on the proposal (Hansard, 12th September 1968, page 1065)?
Did the Ministers consider any other suggestions from other Commonwealth Parliament or Government committees or authorities, such as the National Health and Medical Research Council?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1 and 2. The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works recommended that the Commonwealth should initiate discussions with the States with a view to establishing an agency responsible for the collection, evaluation and dissemination of hospital planning and design information. This matter was discussed at the Conference of Commonweatlh and State Health Ministers in June 1968. It was agreed that a meeting of appropriate Commonwealth and State officers should be convened to discuss the proposal in greater detail.

item.para: Commonwealth and State officers have not yet mct to discuss the proposal but administrative action is being taken towards holding such a meeting.

The Director-General of Health's report for the year ended 30th June 1968 did not specifically refer to this matter as at that stage it had not become a departmental activity. However, his report did contain a reference to the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works following its inquiry into the Woden Valley Hospital project, which endorsed the principles proposed for the construction of that hospital.

The Ministers considered that it would have been premature to include this matter in the public statement following their meeting, as the question needed closer study by each State government and the Commonwealth.

The Ministers considered recommendations by the National Health and Medical Research Council on a number of subjects not related to hospital planning, e.g., labelling of cigarette packages, smallpox vaccinations, etc.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: ls he able to say what proposals are currently foreshadowed by the State Governments or are being considered by the State Parliaments to alter the laws relating to abortion?
If so, would the effects of these measures be to widen dramatically the facilities to terminate pregnancy?
ls he able to say whether the passage of similar legislation in European countries has assisted in the social and demographic decline of those countries?
Are operations to terminate pregnancy on the prescribed list of operations which attract Commonwealth Government support under the National Health Act?

talk.start.para: - The answers lo the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1 and 2. In Western Australia, the Termination of Pregnancy Act was passed, after several amendments, by the State Legislative Council during its last session. The Bill is to be considered by the Legislative Assembly in the Autumn 1969 session. lt will, if passed, legalise termination of pregnancy if two medical practitioners are, in good faith, of the opinion that continuance of the pregnancy would endanger the physical or mental health of the pregnant woman or that there is a substantial risk that, if the child was born, it would suffer such physical or mental abnormalities as to be seriously handicapped. In South Australia it has been foreshadowed that a Bill to amend the laws on the subject of abortion is to be introduced. No information is available as to the extent of changes to be made or when it will be introduced. I am not aware of any changes contemplated in any existing laws on the subject in other States.

item.para: No.

Commonwealth benefits payable for operations are set down in the Schedule to the National Health Act. There are a number of items in the Schedule under which a Commonwealth benefit is payable in respect of operations that result in the termination of a pregnancy. The amount of benefit payable depends on the procedure performed.

subdebateinfo.title: Standardisation of Rail Gauges: South Australia (Question No. 973)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice:

H'ow many miles of South Australia's broad gauge lines and how many units of its broad gauge rolling stock would have to be converted to standard gauge if the 1949 agreement were at least and at last to be carried out to the extent required to link the capital of South Australia with the standard gauge lines in South Australia and the adjoining standard gauge systems in New South Wales and Western Australia?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honour able member's questions are as follows:

item.para: Yes. This was emphasised in the debate when the Railway Standardization (South Australia) Agreement Bill was under consideration in 1949.

The only negotiations between the Commonwealth and the State of Victoria relating to standard gauge railway operations have concerned the construction of a standard gauge railway between Albury and Melbourne. This work was authorised by the Railway Standardization (New South Wales and Victoria) Agreement of 1958 and, of course, has been completed.

It would be possible to link Adelaide with the interstate standard gauge railway by converting the broad gauge line from Adelaide to Port Pirie (a distance of approximately 136 miles), which would involve disruption to the broad gauge system, or by constructing an independent standard gauge line from Adelaide to Crystal Brook, leaving the broad gauge system intact. It has been agreed with the State that these and other matters, including problems relating to the introduction of standard gauge working into the Adelaide metropolitan area and into the Adelaide railway station, will be examined by independent consultants, who will report on the most efficient way of achieving rail standardisation between Adelaide and the interstate railway. Such report also will take account of any new standard gauge rolling stock which would need to be provided, or any broad gauge rolling stock which could be converted.

talk.start.para: ns asked the Prime Minister, upon notice:

item.para: Did the International Commission for Supervision and Control in Vietnam issue a Special Report dated 2nd June 1962, which was published by Her Majesty's Stationery Office as Cmnd 1755?

Did he, in answer to a question on 27th August (Hansard, page 542), quote certain items from that report to show evidence that North Vietnam had sent armed and unarmed personnel, arms, munitions and other supplies into South Vietnam?

Did he, in answer to a question on 29th August (Hansard, page 698) claim that the items quoted gave a complete and accurate view of the Special Report's conclusions about aggression by North and South Vietnam against ear.h ruber?
Were the items quoted by him numbered (2) and (3) of paragraph 9, and do they appear on page 7 of the Report?
Do paragraphs 11 to 20 commence on page 7 of the Report and continue to page 10?
Do these paragraphs record many allegations and findings such as:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the conclusion of a bilateral military agreement between President Ngo Dinh Diem and United States Ambassador Nolting

item.label: (b)
item.para: the gradual introduction of about 5,000 United States military personnel into South Vietnam, which would soon be increased to 8,000;

item.label: (c)
item.para: the arrival of four aircraft carriers - 'Core', Breton', 'Princeton' and 'Croaton' - on different occasions, bringing in helicopters, other aircraft, military equipment and military personnel:

item.label: (d)
item.para: the introduction by the United States of America of approximately four companies of helicopters, many jet fighters, fighters/ fighter bombers and transport planes, along with military vehicles and other stores;

item.label: (e)
item.para: the visits of a large number of high United States military experts and dignitaries to Saigon for inspection and guidance, particularly those of General Maxwell Taylor, Admiral H. Felt and General Lemnitzer

item.label: (f)
item.para: the establishment of a United States Military Assistance Command, with a four-star General, Paul D. Harkins, as its Chief;

item.label: (g)
item.para: the denial of the right of the Commission's Teams in South Vietnam to control and inspect, which was part of their mandatory tasks, and to determine precisely the quantum and nature of war materials unloaded and introduced into South Vietnam;

item.label: (h)
item.para: the flagrant violation of the Geneva Agreement by the Government of the Republic of Vietnam in requesting the Government of the United States of America to intensify the aid in personnel and material which the latter was already granting to Vietnam;

item.label: (i)
item.para: the violations of Article .17 (e) and Article 25 recorded against the Republic of Vietnam for its failure to notify arrivals and imports, and for not affording all possible assistance to the Commission's Teams in the performance of their tasks: and

item.label: (j)
item.para: the violation of Articles 16 and 17 by the Republic of Vietnam in receiving increased military aid from the United States of America in the absence of any established credit in its favour, and the establishment of a United States Military Assistance Command in South Vietnam which amounted to a factual military alliance which was prohibited under Article 19 of the Agreement?
Does the statement of only items (2) and (3) and the omission of any mention of paragraphs 11 to 20 give a complete and accurate view of the Special Report's conclusions?

Does the United States State Department publication 'Aggression from the North' published in February 1965, give prominence also to items (2) and (3), as he did, and omit mention of the Commission's findings against South Vietnam and the United States in paragraph 11 to 20?

If so, does the publication 'Aggression from the North' give a complete and accurate view of the conclusions of the International Commission for Supervision and Control about the movement of men, arms and material upon which it was reporting in the Special Report of 2nd June 1962?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honour able member's questions are as follows:

item.para: Yes.
Yes.

No. The honourable member's question implies that the Special Report contains conclusions about aggression by North and South Vietnam against each other. The Report does not make a"ny such statement; neither did I. My central point is that the Special Report to the CoChairman of the Geneva Conference on Indo-China of 2nd June contains evidence that the zone in the North had been used as a base for aggression against the Armed Forces and Administration of the Zone in the South. This can be seen from paragraph 9 (2) and paragraph 10 of the Report. Paragraph 9 (2) gives the Legal Committee's conclusion 'that armed and unarmed personnel, arms, munitions and other supplies have been sent from the Zone in the North to the Zone in the South with the object of supporting, organising and carrying out hostile activities, including armed attacks directed against the Armed Forces and Administration of the Zone in the South'. This finding was accepted by the Commission at paragraph 10.

The items appear on page 7 of Cmnd 1755, as follows: '(2) Having examined the complaints and the supporting materia] sent by the South Vietnamese Mission, the Committee has come to the conclusion that in specific instances there is evidence to show that armed and unarmed personnel, arms, munitions and other supplies have been sent from the Zone in the North to the Zone in the South with the object of supporting, organising and carrying out hostile activities, including armed attacks, directed against the Armed Forces and Administration of the Zone in the South. These acts are in violation of Articles 10, 19, 24 and 27 of the Agreement on the Cessation of Hostilities in Vietnam. (3) In examining the complaints and the supporting material, in particular documentary material sent by the South Vietnamese Mission, the Committee has come to the further conclusion that there is evidence to show that the PAVN has allowed the Zone in the North to be used for inciting, encouraging and supporting hostile activities in the Zone in the South, aimed at the overthrow of the Administration in the South. The use of the Zone in the North for such activities is in violation of Articles 19, 24 and 27 of the Agreement on the Cessation of Hostilities in Vietnam'.
Paragraphs 11 to 20 begin on page 7 of Cmnd. 1755 and continue to page 10. 6. (a) to (f) These are North Vietnamese allegations which are recorded as such in paragraph 11 of the Report:

item.label: (g)
item.para: The Report includes the Commission's view to this effect.

item.label: (h)
item.para: The reference to 'flagrant violation of the Geneva Agreement' in paragraph 13 reads: In the face of the aggression, directed by the so-called "Democratic Republic of Vietnam against the Republic of Vietnam in flagrant violation of the Geneva Agreement, the Government of the Republic of Vietnam has requested the Government of the United States of America to intensify the aid in personnel and material which the latter was already granting to Vietnam". This is an extract from a communication addressed to the Commission on 9th December 1961 by the Liaison Mission of the Republic of Vietnam.

item.label: (i)
item.para: to (j) Pages 8, 9 and 10 of Cmnd. 1755 refer. 7, 8 and 9. My statement included references to the material in paragraphs 11 to 20 of the Report.

answer.para: Paragraphs 9 (2) and 9 (3) contained conclusions of the Legal Committee. The Commission accepted these conclusions, and 'Aggression from the North', at Appendix A, page 30, not only refers to paragraph 9 (2) and 9 (3) but correctly cites paragraph 10 of the Commission's findings as follows: "The Commission accepts the conclusions reached by the Legal Committee that there is sufficient evidence to show beyond reasonable doubt that the PAVN has violated Articles 10, 19, 24 and 27 in specific instances. The Polish Delegation dissents from these conclusions. On the basis of the fuller report, that is being prepared by the Legal Committee covering all the allegations and incidents, the Commission will take action as appropriate in each individual case.'

Readers are then referred to the full text of the ICC Report contained in a publication, 'Special Report to the Co-Chairmen of the Geneva Conference on Indo-China', issued by the Bureau of Far Eastern Affairs of the Department of State on 2nd July 1962.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

quote.para: Under the present arrangements by which the Commonwealth pays half the cost of any subsidies for the transport of fodder undertaken by the State Government of New South Wales in the drought-stricken areas of Eden-Monaro, in the event of a decision by the State Government to apply a subsidy of 40 cents per bushel on the transport of feed wheat or other grain, in addition to the freight subsidies already available on fodder, would the Commonwealth pay half of the cost of this additional subsidy?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Commonwealth has agreed to meet half the cost in this financial year of relief measures which the New South Wales Government may find it necessary to continue in the South Coast, Southern Tablelands and Cobar districts until the drought breaks. The relief measures for which the Commonwealth has agreed to contribute are those which have been applied in New South Wales drought areas during the past three years. They include the provision of loans for carry on purposes where credit is not available through normal commercial channels; rebates of freight on the transport of fodder and water to drought affected areas and the transport of starving stock out of drought areas; expenditure to provide relief work for those unemployed in rural areas as a result of drought; and miscellaneous expenditure in relation to the drought, such as cloud seeding.

In the case of rebates of freight on the transport of fodder to feed starving stock, the Commonwealth has agreed to meet half the cost of rebates of up to 75 per cent of the total transport cost by rail. Where rail transport is not available the Commonwealth will meet half the cost of rebates of similar proportions of road transport costs. However, the precise details of the subsidy arrangements to apply in any particular area are a matter for the State.

On this basis, the Commonwealth would be prepared to meet half the cost of rebates of up to 75 per cent of the transport cost of feed wheat or other grain to feed starving stock in the South Coast and Southern Tablelands area.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

question.para: Will be consider recommending legislation to remove tax exemption from advertising of tobacco products and alcoholic drinks and to use resulting revenues in (a) advertising to young people the facts about the social and physiological significance of smoking and drinking; (b) alleviating hardship caused to any section of the tobacco or liquor industries by such legislation and (c) alleviating the burden on public revenue due to disease effects of tobacco or alcohol?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The primary purpose of the income tax law is to raise revenue for the Commonwealth. It is a well-established principle of the law that expenses which are incurred in gaining or producing assessable income or which are necessarily incurred in carrying on a business to produce such income, should be allowed as deductions for income tax purposes. It is not considered appropriate to depart from those principles for a purpose which is quite unrelated to the taxation of income.
